intro: Apteranthes europaea var. affinis, commonly known as the European false nettle, is a flowering plant native to Europe. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, white flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows and woodland edges. It is an annual or biennial herb that produces small, dry fruits called schizocarps. The species is notable for its ability to thrive in disturbed habitats and its role in supporting local insect populations.
